p: A groundbreaking comprehensive study was conducted on the state of workforce diversity in the environmental movement by surveying 191 environmental non-profits, 74 government environmental agencies, and 28 leading environmental grantmaking foundations to investigate their gender and racial diversity composition (Taylor 2014). The resulting report, “The State of Diversity in Environmental Organizations,” revealed that “The percentage of ethnic minorities on the boards or general staff of environmental organizations does not exceed 16 percent” (Taylor 2014, p. 4). The report also concluded that, “once hired in environmental organizations, ethnic minorities are concentrated in the lower ranks. As a result, people of color occupy less than 12 percent of the leadership positions in the environmental organizations” (Taylor 2014, p. 4). The constant failure of the green movement to improve these low percentages is known as the “green ceiling,” to indicate that there are barriers to inclusion and active hiring of historically underrepresented individuals within environmental organizations, particularly in leadership roles.
